using-homogeneous-coordinates-to-get-a-l.text: Using Homogeneous Coordinates to get a linear equation

pageProps.body:
Lec 2

Homogeneous Coordinates

Using Homogeneous Coordinates to get a linear equation

From Lec 1
Go to text →
  • the origin of the image sensor may be at the center, thus we consider a principle point with the pixel (ox,oy)(o_x, o_y)(ox​,oy​) and the final equation is given by:
    u=fxxczc+ox,v=fyyczc+oyu = f_x \frac{x_c}{z_c} + o_x \hspace{2mm},\hspace{2mm} v = f_y \frac{y_c}{z_c} + o_yu=fx​zc​xc​​+ox​,v=fy​zc​yc​​+oy​

  • to remove the non-linearity in the above equations, we use the homogeneous coordinates of the image point (u,v)(u, v)(u,v)
    • we bump the dimension using scalar zcz_czc​ to get rid of the denominator
      (u^v^w^)≡(zcu^zcv^zc^)=(fxxc+oxzcfyyc+oyzczc)\begin{pmatrix} \hat{u} \\ \hat{v} \\ \hat{w} \end{pmatrix} \equiv \begin{pmatrix} \hat{z_cu} \\ \hat{z_cv} \\ \hat{z_c} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} {f_xx_c + o_xz_c} \\ {f_yy_c + o_yz_c} \\ {z_c} \end{pmatrix}⎝⎛​u^v^w^​⎠⎞​≡⎝⎛​zc​u^​zc​v^​zc​^​​⎠⎞​=⎝⎛​fx​xc​+ox​zc​fy​yc​+oy​zc​zc​​⎠⎞​
  • to capture the transformation from camera coordinate [xcyczc1][x_c\hspace{2mm}y_c\hspace{2mm}z_c\hspace{2mm}1][xc​yc​zc​1] to the image coordinate [u^v^w^][\hat{u}\hspace{2mm}\hat{v}\hspace{2mm}\hat{w}][u^v^w^], we use a single 3x4 matrix
    (u^v^w^)=(fx0ox00fyoy00010)(xcyczc1)\begin{pmatrix} \hat{u} \\ \hat{v} \\ \hat{w} \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} f_x&0&o_x&0 \\ 0&f_y&o_y&0 \\ 0&0&1&0 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x_c\\y_c\\z_c\\1 \end{pmatrix}⎝⎛​u^v^w^​⎠⎞​=⎝⎛​fx​00​0fy​0​ox​oy​1​000​⎠⎞​⎝⎛​xc​yc​zc​1​⎠⎞​
  • this matrix is known as matrix of intrinsic properties MintM_{int}Mint​ and the inner 3x3 matrix is knows as calibration matrix KKK
    • i.e. M=[K0]M = [K\hspace{2mm}0]M=[K0]
    • K is an upper triangular matrix

World Coordinate to Camera Coordinate

  • this tranfomration is a change of coordinate system and can be characterized by an orthonormal rotation matrix RRR and a translation vector t→\overrightarrow{t}t
    (xcyczc)=(r11r12r13r21r22r23r31r32r33)(xwywzw)+(txtytz)\begin{pmatrix} x_c\\y_c\\z_c \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} r_{11} & r_{12}&r_{13}\\ r_{21}&r_{22}&r_{23}\\ r_{31}&r_{32}&r_{33} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x_w\\y_w\\z_w \end{pmatrix} + \begin{pmatrix} t_x\\t_y\\t_z \end{pmatrix}⎝⎛​xc​yc​zc​​⎠⎞​=⎝⎛​r11​r21​r31​​r12​r22​r32​​r13​r23​r33​​⎠⎞​⎝⎛​xw​yw​zw​​⎠⎞​+⎝⎛​tx​ty​tz​​⎠⎞​
  • this can be rewritten in homogeneous system as
    (xcyczc1)=(r11r12r13txr21r22r23tyr31r32r33tz0001)(xwywzw1)\begin{pmatrix} x_c\\y_c\\z_c\\1 \end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix} r_{11} & r_{12}&r_{13}&t_x\\ r_{21}&r_{22}&r_{23}&t_y\\ r_{31}&r_{32}&r_{33}&t_z\\0&0&0&1 \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix} x_w\\y_w\\z_w\\1 \end{pmatrix}⎝⎛​xc​yc​zc​1​⎠⎞​=⎝⎛​r11​r21​r31​0​r12​r22​r32​0​r13​r23​r33​0​tx​ty​tz​1​⎠⎞​⎝⎛​xw​yw​zw​1​⎠⎞​
  • this in knows as matrix of external parameters MextM_{ext}Mext​ and Mext=(Rt01)M_{ext} = \begin{pmatrix}R&t\\0&1\end{pmatrix}Mext​=(R0​t1​)
  • the projection vector PPP can be expressed as P=MintMintP = M_{int}M_{int}P=Mint​Mint​
